overview.note: "On Wednesday afternoon, at five o'clock, the Honorable Convention of this Commonwealth assented to, and ratified, the Constitution proposed by the late Federal Convention." American Herald (Boston, MA). February 11, 1788.

The following is an account of the yeas and nays of the different counties, in the State Convention of Massachusetts: Barnstable had 7 yeas and 2 nays, Berkshire had 7 yeas and 15 nays, Bristol had 10 yeas and 12 nays, Cumberland had 10 yeas and 3 nays, Dukes had 2 yeas and 0 nays, Essex had 38 yeas and 6 nays, Hampshire had 19 yeas and 33 nays, Lincoln had 9 yeas and 7 nays, Middlesex had 18 yeas and 10 nays, Plymouth had 21 yeas and 6 nays, Suffolk had 33 yeas and 5 nays, Worcester had 7 yeas and 58 nays, and York had 6 yeas and 11 nays. The Hampshire Gazette (Northampton, MA). February 27, 1788.

sub_unit.name: Abraham White
sub_unit.note: "Hon. Mr. White rose, and said, that notwithstanding he had opposed the adoption of the constitution, upon the idea that it would endanger the liberties of his country, yet, as a majority had seen fit to adopt it, he should use his utmost exertions to induce his constituents to live in peace under, and cheerfully submit to it." American Herald (Boston, MA). February 11, 1788.
